comments.content:
Send as permissions are not migrated if the mailboxes involved aren't moved in the same batch:
"Mailbox permissions migration. On-premises mailbox permissions that are explicitly applied on the mailbox are migrated to Exchange Online. These permissions include Send As, Full Access, Send on Behalf of, and folder permissions. [...] For Send As permissions, if the user and the resource attempting to be “sent as” aren’t moved at the same time, the Send As permission must be explicitly added in Exchange Online using the Add-RecipientPermission cmdlet."
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/training/modules/plan-your-hybrid-requirements-for-your-microsoft-365-deployment/2-plan-hybrid-exchange-environment

The answer is YNY then - assuming the same restriction doesn't apply to Full access permissions.

discussion.content: Full access, Send on Behalf of supported in Hybrid Environments. Send As not supported. So YNY

The Send As permission is not supported in hybrid migration between 365 mailbox & on-prem mailbox, but permissions are retained after all mailboxes migrated. I have carried out a hybrid migration twice and can confirm that all permissions were retained (except for permissions granted to non-mail-enabled Security Groups of course).
The only thing that gives me a little pause for thought is that the 2 mailboxes in this scenario are not migrated as part of the same batch.
So for me I think the answer is Y, Y, Y

The three answers are N, N, Y
Here the reasons why:

First N 
While mailbox forwarding is supported in Exchange Online, the forwarding configuration isn't copied to Exchange Online when the mailbox is migrated there. 

For the second N
For Send As permissions, if the user and the resource attempting to be “sent as” aren’t moved at the same time, the Send As permission must be explicitly added in Exchange Online using the Add-RecipientPermission cmdlet.

The last Y
On-premises mailbox permissions that are explicitly applied on the mailbox are migrated to Exchange Online. These permissions include Send As, Full Access, Send on Behalf of, and folder permissions.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/training/modules/plan-your-hybrid-requirements-for-your-microsoft-365-deployment/2-plan-hybrid-exchange-environment

same question in ms-203 (https://www.examtopics.com/discussions/microsoft/view/57695-exam-ms-203-topic-3-question-13-discussion/).

Permissions are maintained as long as the account that has been granted permissions is moved at the same time or has been previously moved

for me NNY

comments.content: I think the forwarding ruler for Q1 will still apply since both users are migrated in the same batch. In a cutover or staged Exchange migration, the mailbox contents, folder permissions, and delegate permissions of the on-premises mailbox are migrated to a new cloud-based mailbox. However, Send As or full mailbox access permissions aren't migrated.

After reviewing this question I believe that all answers here are using a wrong reference. We are not talking aboud hybrid Exchange as all references including my own assume, but a cutover migration in 2 batches. That means that the migrated mailboxes don't know about the remaining on-prem mailboxes, hence last question is also No, so correct answer is N-N-N

discussion.content:
Correct answer is N-N-Y
according to https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/exchange-hybrid#exchange-hybrid-deployment-considerations we have the following scenario:
- Forwarding: While mailbox forwarding is supported in Exchange Online, the forwarding configuration isn't copied to Exchange Online when the mailbox is migrated there.
-SendAs (mailboxes are not migrated within the same batch, so we are talking about a cross-premises scenario): "Support for cross-premises mailbox permissions. ..Additional steps are required for Send As permissions."
- FullAccess (cross-premises): Exchange hybrid deployments support the use of the Full Access and Send on Behalf Of permissions between mailboxes located in an on-premises Exchange organization and mailboxes located in Exchange Online.

Box 1: N: Email forwarding is not migrated by default and needs to be exported before migration
Box 2: N: Although Send As permissions are migrated by default, only 1 of the users is migrated and Send As is not by default supported cross-premise in a hybrid environment
Box 3: Y: Send On Behalve permissions are migrated by default. Only 1 of the users is migrated but Send on behalve is also by default supported cross-premise in a hybrid environment

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/exchange-hybrid#exchange-hybrid-deployment-considerations

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/training/modules/plan-your-hybrid-requirements-for-your-microsoft-365-deployment/2-plan-hybrid-exchange-environment

comments.content:
Correct. Another very explicit source for box 2 and 3 is this one: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/permissions#mailbox-permissions-in-hybrid-environments

For box 1, Startkabel has provided the definite source already: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/exchange-hybrid#exchange-hybrid-deployment-considerations

But also https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/permissions#mailbox-permissions-in-hybrid-environments
"Azure AD Connect doesn't automatically synchronize Send As permission between on-premises Exchange and Microsoft 365 or Office 365, so cross-premises Send As permissions aren't supported."
Perhaps, it's NNY...
Live or die... Make your choice :D

discussion.content:
NYY
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/exchange-hybrid
"While mailbox forwarding is supported in Exchange Online, the forwarding configuration isn't copied to Exchange Online when the mailbox is migrated there."
"On-premises mailbox permissions such as Send As, Full Access, Send on Behalf, and folder permissions, that are explicitly applied on the mailbox are migrated to Exchange Online."

Yes & No & Yes 
(https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/permissions#mailbox-permissions-in-hybrid-environments)

NOT SUPPORT upgrade (but side-by-side migration by implementing new Exchange Servers). I believe the correct answer is Server 5. Lync 2013 can be upgraded (in-place) to Skype for Business 2015 and then configured in hybrid with Office 365.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription.
You plan to implement Microsoft 365 usage analytics reports in Microsoft Power BI.
You need to ensure that the Microsoft 365 usage analytics template app can access Microsoft 365 usage data.
Which Authentication method should you select for Power BI?

Your on-premises network contains an Active Directory domain that syncs with an Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) tenant named contoso.com by using Azure
AD Connect.
Your company purchases another company that has an on-premises Active Directory domain named litwareinc.com.
You need to sync litwareinc.com with contoso.com.
What should you install in the litwareinc.com domain?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Answer is C - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/cloud-sync/what-is-cloud-sync - Azure AD Connect cloud sync - Support for synchronizing to an Azure AD tenant from a multi-forest disconnected Active Directory forest environment: The common scenarios include merger & acquisition (where the acquired company's AD forests are isolated from the parent company's AD forests), and companies that have historically had multiple AD forests.

C seems to be logical answer. Based on MS article: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/hybrid/connect/plan-connect-topologies. Having more than one Azure AD Connect sync server connected to a single Azure AD tenant is not supported. The exception is the use of a staging server.

D. an active instance of Azure AD Connect

You should install an active instance of Azure AD Connect in the litwareinc.com domain to sync it with contoso.com. Azure AD Connect is used to synchronize identity data between on-premises Active Directory and Azure AD (ARTICLE2). According to ARTICLE1, Azure AD Connect cloud sync can be used for connecting multiple disconnected on-premises AD forests. However, since you are already using Azure AD Connect for the existing contoso.com domain, it would be more straightforward and consistent to continue using Azure AD Connect for the newly acquired litwareinc.com domain.

ARTICLE1: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/hybrid/how-to-connect-sync-whatis
ARTICLE2: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/cloud-sync/what-is-cloud-sync

comments.content: There is no specific limit on the number of active instances of Azure AD Connect you can have. However, each Azure AD Connect instance can only sync with one Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) tenant. In scenarios where you have multiple on-premises Active Directory forests, you can use one Azure AD Connect instance to sync all the forests to a single Azure AD tenant, or you can set up multiple instances of Azure AD Connect, each syncing a separate forest with a separate Azure AD tenant.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is correct cause a domain of purchased company has to be added that has a domain that is not connected to the one the purchasing company is using already.

comments.content:
I think C is correct because the Forests/Domains are not connected:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/cloud-sync/what-is-cloud-sync
Since you cannot add a second AAD-Connect Instance, you have to use AAD Cloud Sync in this scenario - therefore Option C (provisioning agent) is correct

discussion.content:
This makes no sense to me.
If you want to sync a second on-prem AD Domain you need to establish a trust and then modify the existing Azure AD Connect Settings to include the second on-prem AD Domain.


you can only have one AD Connect instance per tenant. 
https://www.smikar.com/second-domain-using-ad-connect/

D is correct 
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/hybrid/how-to-connect-sync-whatis

choices.C: an Azure AD Connect provisioning agent
choices.A: an Azure AD application proxy connector
choices.D: an active instance of Azure AD Connect
choices.B: an Azure AD Connect instance in staging mode
